documents.title: waveney words audio news service chooses listener to take on role of chairman for the first time
text: an audio news service which covers the waveney valley has chosen one of its listeners to take on the role of chairman for the first time .

waveney words , a `` talking newspaper '' which provides news for the blind , unanimously elected roydon resident audrey moskowitz , after committee members realised they had never had a listener in the lead role .
author: Diss Express

documents.title: body found in city river
text: the body of a woman has been found in water near to new mills yard in norwich .
police and fire officers carried out a search of the river this morning and found the body at 11:00 .
formal identification of the body is yet to take place , but norfolk police say the woman is believed to be sarah `` topsy '' gardner .
the 60-year-old was last seen at her home address on sprowston road in the early hours of saturday , 18 march .
investigations are continuing , by the death is not currently being treated as sus

documents.title: minister keen to avoid press in norwich
text: there were bizarre scenes outside a norwich care complex this afternoon as the health secretary paid a visit , but went to great lengths to avoid the press .
jeremy hunt was smuggled in through a back door at the meadows retirement village in bowthorpe and at the end of the visit he was driven away at speed .
no reason has been given for his apparent shyness
the meadows is a new complex of 92 apartments designed for people with dementia .
it is something you might have expected the health secretary to want to talk about .
the county council would not allow journalists to follow the visit , citing election `` purdah '' rules which ban campaigning on council premises during election periods .
however , photographers were told they could wait outside to film mr hunt 's arrival .
but he clearly had other ideas .
we briefly saw him in the main reception area and he was also seen on the roof looking out over the complex .
the department of health said mr hunt was on a political visit , the conservative party has n't made any comment .
i 'm told that the health secretary was impressed at what he saw and said that he wants to see more such retirement villages .
photographers briefly spy health sec on roof of care home but he 's still avoiding us
hi andrew , which care home was this , please ?
just seeing if on our patch .
many thanks
author: Andrew Sinclair
BBC Look East political correspondent

documents.title: uk 's arrival of raf stealth jet takes step forward
text: the arrival in norfolk of the raf 's new f-35 lightning ii has taken a step forward .

us company lockheed martin has been awarded a £ 80m contract by the ministry of defence/us department of defense to deliver the initial training , engineering , maintenance and logistics support for the raf 's fleet of the fast jets over a three year period .
it 's subcontracted £ 40m worth of the work to bae systems .
together the two companies will form a team of more than 100 skilled technicians at raf marham , providing engineering and technical expertise , routine maintenance , air and ground crew training .
work is already under way at the west norfolk airbase for the arrival of 617 squadron , which will fly the uk 's initial operational f-35 lightning ii jets from 2018 .
in .
april last year , lockheed martin was awarded a multi-million pound contract to deliver an aircraft maintenance and training centre at raf marham .
defence secretary sir michael fallon made today 's announcement during a press conference with his us counterpart james mattis .
nothing demonstrates the strength of our relationship better than our joint work on the most advanced combat aircraft in the world - the f-35 lightning ii .

the additional investment at raf marham will ensure that we have a formidable fighting force that , at a time of growing danger , will help us work with our us partners to promote international peace and security . ''

documents.title: funds to help save rare species
text: breckland is getting nearly £ 500,000 to try and protect rare species which are in danger of dying out .
the `` back from the brink '' project has been awarded £ 4.6m from the heritage lottery fund .
the landscape of the area is unusual because of its climate and geology , and has the lowest rainfall in the country .
with its mix of chalk and sandy soils , and history of human habitation , it 's led to the creation of unique habitats such as grass heath and inland sand dunes .
karen kramer is the development officer behind the three-year project , which will help 16 rare species , including invertebrates , reptiles and birds .
all the species we 're looking at are ones that are predicted potentially to go extinct by 2020 .

we 're looking at things which are on the brink of being lost - stone curlew [ and woodlark are two people might recognise - and we have some really unique and special beetles , one of them is called the wormwood moonshiner . ''

text: just how did those legs end up there ?
find out with our top 10 magic moments from last weekend 's fa people 's cup semi-finals .

documents.title: top marks for primary school
text: it 's 10 out of 10 for pupils at a north norfolk school .
aldborough primary , near aylsham , has achieved 100 % in its key stage 2 reading tests , putting it in the top 1 % of schools nationally .
the school has received a big tick from education minister , nick gibb .
he sent a letter to head teacher tina casburn , praising the school for its high standards .

the university of east anglia regularly sends education students to the school to see how it teaches reading , and other schools from across the county have also gone to learn about its unusual approach .

we do n't use reading schemes , we do n't focus too much on phonics it flies against most conventional thinking but , believe it or not , if you give a child decent books , and nurture their ability to really understand them , they actually enjoy reading . ''

documents.title: high hopes for morello racing
text: norwich-based .
morello racing begin their season at donington this weekend as one of the favourites to take the superstock 1000 title .
the series follows the british superbike championship around the uk .
they 've signed former superbike rider danny buchan this year as well as retaining fraser rogers .
team owner steve buckingham said : `` you 've got major amounts of pedigree there , pre-season testing has gone very well . ''
author: Chris Goreham
BBC Radio Norfolk sport

documents.title: semi-final challenge for canaries youngsters
text: norwich city under 23 's play sunderland at carrow road this evening in the semi-final of the premier league international cup .
the winners will play fc porto at home in the final .
norwich city 's academy director richard money is hoping the game will attract a big crowd .
`` we 've shown that this is a really good competition and the young boys are really worth coming to watch . ''
money said .

documents.title: norwich city resume play-off push at aston villa
text: norwich city go to aston villa tomorrow in the championship .
with eight matches to play the canaries are five points adrift of the play-offs and many supporters gave up any hope of a top six finish some time ago .
but it 's worth remembering that in 2002 , when city reached the play-off final in cardiff , they were six points adrift at the same stage .
craig fleming was a member of that team and he joined us on last night 's edition of the scrimmage .
on bbc radio norfolk
`` they 're right in the mix , i think .
it 's a two-game swing , if the teams above them lose two games and they win two , that 's it , they 're in the box seat , '' said fleming .
author: Chris Goreham
BBC Radio Norfolk sport

the cloud 's expected to break up this afternoon , bringing sunny spells , but also the chance of a shower .
not quite as warm as yesterday , with temperatures peaking at 17c ( 63f ) .

documents.title: college retains 'good ' rating
text: a four-day inspection by ofsted inspectors has led to norwich city college being rated `` good '' for overall effectiveness .
it was ranked `` outstanding '' for its provision for students with high needs .
the report noted the quality of teaching , learning and assessment was good , with the majority of teachers provided good feedback .
but it also found that not enough learners improve in english and maths skills , and too few of those studying a levels make the progress needed to achieve higher grades .
nearly .
7,000 students attend the college , and it 's the largest provider of apprenticeships in norfolk and suffolk .
principal corrienne peasgood says the report recognises the way its industry-standard facilities and teaching staff help students to realise their career aspirations .

documents.title: 'job at risk ' claims union
text: a union is claiming that up to 80 jobs could be at risk at norfolk county council 's children 's services department .
it 's alleged that staff were called into a briefing earlier this week in which they were told dozens of jobs could be at risk .
jonathan dunning is the branch secretary of unison and he says it 's come as a shock to his members .
`` this seems to have been a bolt from the blue , '' he said
`` there was no anticipation such cuts were coming , there 's been no dialogue with unison and the first staff were told about it was at a meeting they have with their managers . ''
the council 's managing director wendy thomson says the cuts are not in the area of care that ofsted is looking at .
in a statement , norfolk county council says it needs to make £ 4m of cuts , and they 're drawing up changes to their education services .
they ca n't say how many redundancies will be necessary at this stage .

documents.title: the broads - a national park or not ?
text: a sign to welcome visitors to the `` broads national park '' was unveiled at beccles railway station earlier , by defra minister lord gardiner .
but is britain 's largest protected wetland an actual national park ?
well , not quite
the broads cover an area of 303 sq km , and is home to more than a quarter of the uk 's rarest wildlife .
the lakes are man-made , dug out for peat to provide fuel during medieval times .
over the centuries , these filled in to become the broads that we recognise today .

documents.title: first of many signs welcoming visitors to broads national park
text: the defra minister lord gardiner has unveiled the first broads national park sign .
the broads authority plans to install a network of signs welcoming people to the park , in villages , towns and at other key locations .
it 'll work with local authorities and rail companies to identify suitable sites .
national parks minister lord gardiner unveils the first broads national park train station sign at beccles !
would love these on our bittern and wherry lines stations
just what the broads need .

documents.title: no kidding goats move into summer residence
text: now that the weather 's turned finer , a herd of bagot billies have taken up residence in their spring and summer home on cromer 's cliffs .
the eight-strong herd have spent the recent months clearing land in the happy valley area .
the goats were brought in by north norfolk district council ( nndc ) last year as a cheaper - and natural - way of clearing the land of overgrown vegetation .
the bagots were very popular with visitors , says councillor angie fitch-tillett , and did a `` fabulous job '' at managing the habitat .
but the goat herd will expand another eight bagots from cumbria will be joining them in may .

it 's excellent there 'll be an addition to the herd an extra attraction for our visitors and also an extended area which will be naturally-managed by these brilliant undergrowth-clearing machines . ''

documents.title: city centre attacks : more time to question suspect
text: police say they 've been given more time to question a 22-year-old man in connection with a string of offences in norwich yesterday .
the attacks on three women and two robberies all happened between 04:30 and 07:30 .
officers were first called to ten bell court shortly after 06:30 , to reports a woman had been assaulted and raped .
another woman has reported being sexually assaulted by a man two hours before , on riverside road .
a third woman was physically assaulted in st stephens underpass , and two men were robbed , but uninjured .
police are appealing for witnesses to any of the incidents .

documents.title: 'no rush ' to replace interim director of children 's services
text: matt dunkley has recently taken up the post of interim director of norfolk 's children 's services department following the resignation of former head michael rosen .
the county counci 's managing director wendy thompson says he 's doing a good job , and they 're in no rush to find a replacement .

`` matt has given confidence to the partners that we are absolutely dependent on to make good children 's services i do n't think it 's a question of interim or not , it 's a question or the experience and skill with which he 's approaching it . ''
the latest interim report from ofsted follows a two-day visit at the beginning of march .
the .
last full inspection .
was in 2015 .
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: darts : a hollow victory for suffolk 's wright
text: mendham darts player peter wright was handed a 7-0 victory in the premier league last night after his opponent kim huybrechts withdrew from the event .
the belgian , who was due to be eliminated from the competition after this round , has returned home to be with his mother who is terminally ill .
speaking on stage wright said : `` all our thoughts are with kim and his family . ''
the 46-year-old uk open champion remains second in the table , behind world number one michael van gerwen , who hammered dave chisnall 7-1 .
author: Brenner Woolley
BBC Radio Suffolk sport

documents.title: children 's services 'improving ' but there 's still work to be done
text: norfolk 's children 's services department is making improvements , according to an interim report from ofsted .
but there 's still work to be done .
the service , which has been dogged by poor performance issues , was rated `` inadequate '' 18 months ago .
the latest judgement from ofsted is an interim report , so it would n't have changed the inspectorate 's rating .
there are a lot of positives in the report including praise for changes in structure and management .
ofsted says morale has improved and staff are moving in the right direction .
but overall it 's still not providing a good or consistent enough service .
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

text: it 's been confirmed that shooting will take place in norwich next week for a major new film .
`` fighting with my family '' is about wwe wrestler paige ( in black ) and her family , who are from norwich .
it 's being produced by dwayne `` the rock '' johnson and directed by stephen merchant .
the city council 's been told filming will take place on monday and tuesday - but the locations are `` top secret '' .

documents.title: what 's your tipple ?
text: maybe you like to end your day with a g & t ?
if so , you 'll be pleased to know that a dry gin distilled in our `` fine city '' has been named the world 's best london dry .
produced by bullards spirits at the ten bells pub , the norwich dry gin beat off nine other gins from around the world to scoop the award .
it 's the only gin distillery in the county , and co-founder russell evans says the award was `` a huge shock '' , but also a `` huge pat on the back . ''
our distiller peter smith ( is one of the youngest distillers in the uk and has so many innovative ideas and expertise to bring to our brand .
we only launched a year ago , but already we are achieving more than we thought possible . ''

documents.title: gp surgery among top 4 % in country
text: a gp surgery in north norfolk is the first in the district to be be rated as `` outstanding '' by the care quality commission ( cqc ) .
inspectors from the health watchdog inspected ludham and stalham green surgeries in january .
the practice was praised for delivering well-led and caring services , and promoting good outcomes for patients .
staff were also commended for arranging local meetings and events in conjunction with external support agencies , such as age uk and for hosting the monthly alzheimer 's society dementia cafe .
it 's the first surgery in north norfolk to be given the rating , which puts them in the top 4 % of practices in the country .

documents.title: witness appeal to city centre attacks
text: police have launched an investigation into a rape , two robberies and an assault which happened within an hour of each other in the centre of norwich this morning .
officers were first called to ten bell court in the pottergate area shortly 06:30 to reports a woman had been assaulted and raped .
in a separate incident , a woman also contacted police to say she 'd been physically assaulted in the underpass in st stephen 's .
she suffered minor facial injuries .
two men were robbed in separate incidents in theatre street and london street .
a 22-year-old man has been arrested in connection with these incidents and is being held at wymondham police centre for questioning .
during the investigation of these incidents , police were made away of a further report which may be linked .
at around 04:30 a woman reported being sexually assaulted on riverside road .
police are appealing for anyone with information to contact them .
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: parents escape fine for taking children out of school
text: a couple who faced a £ 240 fine for taking their two children out of school for a week have lost their fight in court .
matt and kerry thomas , of norwich , said it was the only way they could afford a family holiday .
in june last year , they took 11-year-old faith and her brother cain , 14 , to majorca .
the holiday cost them £ 1,800 , but would have cost £ 3,000 if they 'd gone during school holidays .
the children are pupils at catton grove primary and hellesdon high .
both school heads said the week away affected their education .
the local authority 's rules are clear if a child misses school for five days in a row the law has been broken .
faith and cain were away for seven consecutive days .
a spokesperson for norfolk county council say it 's the head teachers who decide whether or not to follow guidance and take action about absences .
mr and mrs thomas escaped a fine at norwich magistrates ' court today - they were given a nine month conditional discharge .
author: Alex Dunlop
BBC Look East

documents.title: sad loss for diss as historic oak set to be cut down
text: diss residents have expressed sadness at the impending loss of an oak tree which has stood in the town for more than two centuries .

the tree on the green in willbye avenue , believed to have once tethered elephants belonging a travelling circus decades ago , is in the process of being chopped down , after safety concerns were outlined by site owners saffron housing .
author: Diss Express

documents.title: terrorist victim 's promise to wife
text: more on tony and chris callaghan , who 've been telling bbc radio norfolk 's nick conrad of how they 'd become separated during a tunisia terror attack at the imperial marhaba hotel in sousse , two years ago .
tony was barricaded inside a hotel office , and his wife was lying injured in the corridor outisde - just a few feet away .
she 'd been shot through her right thigh as she was running from the gunman .
although badly injured herself , chris keep talking to a woman who 'd been injured and kept slipping in unconsciousness .

`` every time she went quiet , i would shake her , touch her i got to know her name , where she lived her husband was standing there shaking , petrified , he did n't know what to do i did n't think i was going to die , it never crossed my mind . ''
they could still hear gunfire , followed by a lull and then `` a really heavy gun battle , incessant gunfire we thought maybe the police or army , and our help was coming . ''
it then quietened down , and tony was able to get out to chris .

she was propped up against a wall , i knelt down and we gave each other a hug and i said no matter what injuries we 've got , we 'll get through this together and that was a promise i 've made to her and i 'm keeping . ''

documents.title: campaigner 's son wants to don helmet as tribute to mother
text: returning to our story about the councillor who died in a fire
the son of a campaigner who was killed in a house blaze says he 's going to follow his mother 's example .
tracey swann , a heacham parish councillor , had campaigned to save the village fire station after it was earmarked for possible closure .
last september , she died in a fire at her caley street home .
ms swann was one of dozens of volunteers given awards for their service at a ceremony in king 's lynn last night .
tanner swann says his mother served heacham fire station and he is hoping to join the norfolk fire and rescue service .
after they did everything they could to save her , the least i can do is help . ''
author: Jill Bennett
BBC Radio Norfolk

documents.title: dilemma faced by terror victim
text: many tourists were injured , and 38 killed , when a gunman opened fire on a tunisian beach resort in june 2015 .
tony and chris callaghan , from north walsham , had fled to the safety of the hotel when they heard gunfire in the stairwell .
tony told bbc radio norfolk 's nick conrad that `` people were in total panic , absolutely terrified , screaming we knew he was n't far behind us '' .
i still live with the guilt of that today i do n't know what i could have done . ''
they started to run but the gunman appeared behind them , at the end of the corridor .
`` he opened fire on us all with his ak47 , he sprayed us all i felt a burning sensation in my left calf , i thought i 'd caught it on a jagged edge and carried on running . ''
six of them piled into an office , barricading themselves in and then tony realised his wife was n't there .
`` i heard chris shouting , tony please help me , i 've been shot and my heart sank . ''
tony says he was trapped with a dilemma - did he open the door , potentially letting the gunman in or comfort his wife by shouting at her , to find out how she was . ''

documents.title: tunisian terror attack victim tells of their ordeal
text: a couple from north walsham , who were injured in the tunisian beach massacre two years ago , have spoken to bbc radio norfolk 's nick conrad about their ordeal .
tony and chris callaghan had been on the beach at sousse for only a few minutes when a gunman armed with a kalasnikov and hand grenades opened fire .
tony said they heard `` gunshots , long burst of automatic fire followed by shot bursts '' .
he 'd seen a motor boat doing tight turns in the water and thought they were being attacked from the sea .
he told his wife to run , shouting warnings to tourists on the beach and around the poolside .
a lot of them thought it was firecrackers , but tony , who 'd fired many automatic weapons during his 23-year career with the royal air force , knew the sound of gunfire .
`` it 's a very distinct whistle when you hear a gunshot quite near and i heard these two whistles going over my head and thought it was time for me to go . ''
he grabbed his bag , and ran to the hotel , where he was reunited with his wife.. and then they heard gunfire within the hotel .
bbc : tunisia attack - what happened ?

documents.title: blackbirds take pole position
text: the rspb big garden birdwatch results are out , and once again the blackbird is top of the pecking order in norfolk .
the house sparrow flew in to take second place .
but starlings have ruffled a few feathers , knocking blue tits off their perch , to take third position in norfolk .
around 12,000 people , including 1,500 school children , spent an hour counting the birds over the last weekend in january .
across the uk as a whole , the house sparrow was the most-spotted species .

text: police are describing a string of attacks which took place within a short space of time in norwich earlier today as `` unprecedented '' .
they were called to the vicinity of chapelfield gardens shortly after 06:30 to reports that a woman had been raped .
in further incidents , two men were robbed and a woman was physically assaulted in the underpass of st stephens .
insp chris burgess says they now believe there was another sexual assault on a woman before all these attacks took place .
the offences are being linked , and a 22-year-old man is in custody .
a number of police officers are working on the investigation , and patrols will be increased in the areas where the attacks took place .
anybody who has seen anything sus is asked to contact the police particularly around the rape as there are suggestions the woman was dragged along the street by the male . ''

documents.title: award for victim of house fire
text: the family of a west norfolk parish councillor who died in a house fire have collected an award on her behalf .
tracey swann from heacham ran a successful campaign against the proposed closure of the village fire station .
but she died when a fire broke out in her home last year .
ms swann was one of dozens of volunteers recognised in a ceremony at king 's lynn town hall last night .
the mayor 's awards are for the unsung heroes of the borough .
tracey 's mother margaret said her daughter would always help anybody in need .
any cause , she would go for it .

the bells !
a campaign to boost the art of bell-ringing in norfolk has received a cash injection from the heritage lottery fund .

it 's now £ 260,200 better off .

documents.title: officers who saved stab victim 's life to be honoured
text: five police officers who saved the life of a man in great yarmouth are to receive honours .
the team were called out to an incident in queen street on boxing day , 2015 .
a man had been losing lots of blood from a stab wound to his neck .
instead of waiting for an ambulance the officers ferried him directly to hospital , where vital minutes helped saved his life .
now , the royal humane society is awarding the officers certificates of commendation for their quick thinking .
sgt adrian hales ( below , top right ) was one of the police officers involved .
`` it was just a normal call on a normal day , '' he told bbc radio norfolk .
`` we joined to serve the public .
we joined to save lives . ''
the other officers to be honoured are pcs constance duffield , andrew featherstone ( bottom left ) , lewis gilmore ( bottom right ) and dean harrison ( not
author: Orla Moore

documents.title: photographic pioneer 's work now on permanent display at cromer museum
text: olive edis was ahead of her time .
the norfolk photographer captured everything from the fishermen off the coast to prime ministers , royalty and writers .
many of her photos were in colour .
now a new exhibition of her work is to go on permanent display at cromer museum .
at the same time , a new touring exhibition exploring her photography is opening at the north norfolk district council offices .
edis - who had a studio in sheringham - is regarded as the first female war photographer , travelling to france to capture the battlefields in 1918 .
she was commissioned by the national war museum , now the imperial war museum , to photograph women at war .
she died in 1955 at the age of 79 .
author: Orla Moore
BBC Local Live

documents.title: police officers killed in wartime air raids remembered
text: here 's one of the two plaques unveiled today to remember the police officers killed in wartime air raids more than 75 years ago .
twelve norfolk police officers died in what was one of the worst attacks in the east of world war two .
during the attack 4,000 incendiaries were dropped .
seventeen people died - and 68 were injured .
among the dead were police war reservists and special constables , killed when a parachute mine landed close to their station in yarmouth .
a second plaque is being unveiled in norwich .
author: Orla Moore
BBC Local Live

documents.title: murder accused refuses to appear at old bailey via video link
text: the man charged with the murder of a norwich mother-of-two has today refused to appear on a prison video link at the old bailey .
the body of kerri mcauley , 32 , was discovered at a flat in southalls way on 8 january .

joe storey , 26 , of murrells court , st john street , norwich , refused to appear on the video link between the judge at the old bailey and the case barristers who were sitting at norwich crown court .
judge anthony bate adjourned the case to norwich until 19 april , when mr storey will have to attend in person .
he was remanded in custody .
author: Orla Moore

documents.title: tribute paid to 'comical little lad ' killed in norfolk collision
text: the family of a young man killed in a road collision last friday have paid a poignant tribute .
jack southey , 22 , died in hospital two hours after the incident on burgh road , bradwell , near great yarmouth .
his family said he `` had such a happy life '' and was a `` comical little lad '' , and that they had treasured their last holiday together .
`` he was well liked by everyone ; he walked everywhere so people would have seen him walking around , everyone knew him .
we miss him deeply , '' they said in a statement .
`` we had a magical family holiday last year ; we went to florida .
florida was his happy place , he loved it there .
we are so glad that we had one last family holiday together .
`` we would like to thank everybody for their support at this difficult time .
the police , ambulance staff and hospital staff were brilliant on the night .
they did everything that they could . ''
he is below with his mother jeanette , father nigel and sister hannah .

documents.title: brexit : what 's in it for the east ?
text: the forthcoming brexit negotiations will be conducted at a local level but there are a number of areas which local mps will be closely watching .
top of the list , by common consent , is science and technology , for which cambridge is an important centre .
hi-tech firms and researchers across the region have benefitted from european investment and partnerships .
while the government has promised that funding for the sector will continue , mps also want to ensure international cooperation and shared trials can continue without disruption .

ease of movement is another big wish : those research companies want to be able to bring in staff from europe and send people abroad without hassle , farmers need foreign workers to help with the harvest and care homes are worried about losing staff .
a lot of the food we grow stays in the uk but food producers still want to be able trade with europe with few , if any barriers .
fishermen hope we 'll have full control of our waters again and be able to resurrect an industry in decline .

ports like felixstowe will be affected by any changes in trade tariffs , airports like stansted and southend will hope that the open skies policy stays in place while all our universities want to be able to continue exchanges and shared courses .
many mps see brexit as an opportunity but they all accept that getting there is likely to be a complicated process .
author: Andrew Sinclair
BBC Look East political correspondent

documents.title: twelve police officers killed in wartime air raids to be remembered
text: two ceremonies are beginning now in norwich and great yarmouth to remember victims of a wartime bombing raid .
the early hours of 8 april , 1941 , norfolk was caught up in one of the region 's worst air raid attacks of world war two .
during the attack 4,000 incendiaries fell .
seventeen people were killed and 68 injured .
among them were 12 police officers , including war reservists and special constables , after a parachute mine landed close to their station in yarmouth .
today , 76 years , two plaques will be unveiled commemorating the tragedy .
norfolk 's chief constable simon bailey said : `` after extensive research this will be the first dedication by norfolk police to remember the specials that died during the war .
`` the event was one of the worst that our county saw and the work of our officers should be recognised . ''
at midday today we hold two ceremonies in yarmouth and norwich to remember the men who fell during the war >
co pearson will be laying a wreath in gy and a/sci gant will be reading act of remembrance in norwich .
author: Orla Moore
BBC Local Live

documents.title: britain must act 'with dignity ' as some feel 'trepidation ' at departure says mep
text: patrick o'flynn , ukip mep for the east of england , says britain should conduct itself `` with dignity '' as article 50 is triggered .
yesterday theresa may signed a letter which will formally begin the process of leaving the eu , and it will be handed to the president of the european council around lunchtime .
mr o'flynn said : `` it would be really stupid to go around gloating and to ignore the fact that at least there 's trepidation and worse among the 16 million people who voted to remain .
`` so we have a heavy responsibility to conduct ourselves with dignity .
so far i 'm relatively reassured with how theresa may is approaching it and i 'm sure we will come together ; of course we will . ''

documents.title: brexit : view from the farmers ' union in norfolk
text: the chairman of the national farmers ' union in norfolk says he 's confident that farming will always be strong , whatever the outcome of britain 's exit from the eu .

tony bambridge said : `` i 'm pretty optimistic there 's always going to be a need for a farming industry , because let 's face it , we all want to eat three meals a day , so therefore , people are always going to need food , and we 're only 60 % self-sufficient for food in the uk . ''
however , he said , the union was not without concerns and feared agriculture may become a `` bargaining chip '' as a deal was sought for banking , financial services or the car industry .
`` so we end up with a bit of a raw deal in order to get these other industries and the employment that they give , '' he said .

documents.title: duchess to attend theatre opening night in support of hos appeal
text: the duchess of cambridge is to attend the opening night of a broadway show in london , in support of the nook appeal .
the duchess , who 's royal patron of east anglia 's children 's hos ( each ) , helped launch the appeal in 2014 to build a new purpose-built facility for the charity on the outskirts of norwich .
in january she visited the hos at quidenham , where she met families and staff , and heard how the appeal is halfway towards its target of £ 10m .
she 'll attend the opening night of 42nd street at london 's theatre royal on tuesday , 4 april .
theatre producers michael grade , michael linnitt and colleagues will be supporting the appeal for the run of the show , and already one donor has pledged £ 250,000 .
each executive director graham butland says he hopes the audience will dig deep , too .

it is fantastic that we have already received a very generous donation and we hope that during the evening the audience will help us raise even more money to make our vision a reality - it would be wonderful if with the support of everyone involved we could reach £ 420,000 . ''

documents.title: marshes 'not the place to be on a cold and misty night '
text: allen frary , coxswain of wells lifeboat , was involved in the rescue of a couple whose sailing adventure at the coast went wrong when their boat began to sink .
he told me the two casualties were in `` the early stages of hypothermia '' when the crew brought them back to the lifeboat house in wells .
`` the gentleman had tried to swim one of the creeks , the water 's very damn cold at this time of year any longer and it would have been a more severe case of hypothermia , '' he said .
the lifeboat crew gave them hot drinks and blankets , and they were tended to by the ambulance service .
the couple , from norwich , had a tent with them and planned on camping for the night .
they were advised not to and the lifeboat crew found them accommodation at a local youth hostel .
`` i presume they stayed there their intention was to collect their bikes this morning , cycle to sheringham and then get the train back to norwich , '' said mr frary .
he warned that while the marshes might look benign during the day , they 're not the place to be on a cold and misty night - particularly if you find yourself in trouble .

maybe 10 miles inland it 's gorgeous sunshine , but the weather on the coast can be completely different the tides ; you can get cut off in the marshes in the dark , there are creeks , gullies i 'm a local and i 've fell in and i know my way around the marshes . ''
author: Jill Bennett
BBC Radio Norfolk

documents.title: meet the baby meerkats
text: after months hiding in their nest boxes , these four baby meerkats are taking their first brave steps into the outside world .
the litter of four siblings were born at banham zoo in january , but it 'll be a few more months before their keepers are able to find out what sexes the pups are .
then they 'll be given names , in keeping with their south african habitat rather than those you might have seen in a certain tv advert .
the four youngsters are expected to remain at the home , along with their parents and another six meerkats .

BBC Local Live

documents.title: original status quo drummer to join redgrave 's walkway on stage for rick parfitt tribute
text: original status quo drummer john coghlan will join redgrave rockers walkway on stage this friday when they perform their tribute to rick parfitt for the very first time .

walkway supported the legendary musicians on numerous occasions and recorded the parfitt-written track 'rain ' on their third album , which will be released later this year and features coghlan , in his memory .
author: Diss Express

documents.title: lucky escape for marsh rescue couple
text: now back to our earlier story on the couple rescued from marshes after their boat became began to sink .
wells lifeboat was called to their aid .
spokesman peter rainsford explained what happened .
`` we had an approximate position but there 's a network of creeks out there , twice every day millions of tons of north sea come in and change the landscape quite dramatically , '' he said .

`` locating people can be difficult in the creek network you can only see the one you 're in , not the one that might be 50 yards away because the marsh is between you there was also quite a bit of mist about . ''
the couple , from norwich , had swum to the edge of a creek before they realised they needed help .
after calling the coastguard , they shone the light from their phone to guide the lifeboat crew to their position .
in a. similar incident last week , the lifeboat crew were able to find a couple and their two dogs who had become cut off by the incoming tide .
their son had guided the inshore lifeboat to his parents by shining a powerful torch from the opposite creek .
the two casualties in last night 's rescue had not told anybody where they were going , or what they were doing .
if their phone had got wet when they were swimming across the creek , nobody would have known they were out there mobile phones are not very reliable means of safety . ''

documents.title: academy sponsorship ends
text: downham market academy is being dropped by its sponsor , following concerns about the speed of improvements at the school .
in november , government inspectors raised concerns about performance and achievement at the west norfolk academy .
they wrote to the college of west anglia academy trust ( cwa ) , which runs the school , warning it to make swift improvements .
in a letter to parents last week , the cwa says that although the school has improved this year , it 's been agreed that it will no longer continue its sponsorship .

the trust 's chief executive , duncan ramsey , says it does n't yet know who the school 's new sponsor will be or when the change will take place , but he assures parents that the current management will stay on until a new backer is found .
author: Nanette Aldous
BBC Radio Norfolk

documents.title: cancer researcher warns against self-medication
text: although deryn blackwell is now fit and well , and hopes to train as a vegan chef , the threat of his cancer returning is still there .
his mum callie said it was always in the back of their minds , but that they took each day as it came .
after secretly giving her son cannabis oil to alleviate his pain , she 's been astounded by the results .
the beneficial effects of cannabis oil have not yet been proven , however .
dr peter mccormick , a cancer researcher at the university of surrey , says its studies suggest it can have the opposite effect .
dr mccormick does n't advocate self-medication , as it can be `` quite risky '' .
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: mum feared losing her sons over cannabis oil decision
text: teenager deryn blackwell had spent years fighting two cancers , and it was n't an an easy decision for his mum callie to break the law by giving him son cannabis oil to ease his suffering .
`` i was worried about the implications he was looking at five years for taking it , and for me actually an even longer sentence for giving it to him , '' she said .

`` i was terrified that social services were going to get involved , i have a younger son as well , i was worried they were going to turn up and take him away from me ; i was afraid i was going to lose all my children . ''
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: cannabis oil 'brought teen from brink of death '
text: callie blackwell says her son 's condition improved after she secretly gave him cannabis oil to ease his suffering .
deryn had been fighting two forms of cancers , one so rare it had only been recorded in 50 other people .
deryn is now 17 , fit and healthy .
he and his mum came into our studios , where they spoke about their `` rollercoaster '' ride .
ms blackwell said there were many times when they 'd been promised deryn was getting better , but he 'd deteriorated further .
`` everybody thought he was dying , '' she said .
`` i 'd filled in the 'do not resuscitate ' forms , every ounce of care other than palliative had been taken away from him ; he was literally on his own , we were waiting for him to die . ''
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: cannabis oil 'helped teenager with cancer '
text: you may have seen a story in the papers at the weekend of callie blackwell , the watton mother who says her teenage son made a recovery from cancer after she gave him cannabis oil to relieve his pain .
deryn , 17 , was first diagnosed with leukaemia and a rare cell cancer in 2013 .
after chemotherapy and bone marrow transplants , he was given days to live and admitted to a hos
in secret , his mum turned to cannabis oil to ease his pain .
she 's now written a book about their ordeal , and says she 'd like a debate and research into the effects the oil could have for others .
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: new £ 1 coin in your pocket
text: the new £ 1 coin comes into circulation today .
it 's being introduced because the old one became so easy to copy - one in 30 is a fake .
the new 12-sided coin has a number of security features including tiny lettering , and a `` £ `` sign which changes in the light like a hologram .
the old coin remains legal tender until 15 october .
dr richard farmer , from the university of east anglia , has researched the history of coins and says the new one may take some getting used to .

we may be moving to a more coinless or cashless society , but we still hanker after the touch and physical presence of money when we touch a new coin for the first time it 's a shock but when we go back to an old coin that 's familiar we know what it 's worth and we know its value to us . ''

documents.title: 'your waste is your responsibility ' says council
text: a campaign has been launched to get residents in north lynn to take more responsibility for their waste .
king 's lynn borough council says it wo n't go on cleaning the alleyways that run behind terraced properties off loke road .
but locals have told me that people often fly tip in the area , leaving the alleyways blocked with debris and smelly waste .
one man told me how they 'd seen everything from mattresses to a whole bedroom suite , which the residents had to move so they could get down the alleyway .

another resident told me the council does it 's best to clear the alley , but that many of the homes are rented , adding that `` when tenants move out they leave their rubbish rather thank taking it to charity shops '' .

having been booed by sections of the hampden park crowd when he was brought on as a replacement for james morrison .
speaking on the monday night club on bbc radio 5 live , russell martin described his namesake as `` one of the most mentally strong players i have played with . ''
he added : `` i think he 's under-appreciated by people who watch the game but he 's certainly appreciated by the players he plays with . ''

documents.title: couple rescued from marshes
text: wells lifeboat was called to the rescue of a young couple from marshes last night .
the pair , from norwich , got into difficulty between wells and stiffkey when their boat began to sink .
they swam to the edge of the creek , but had to call for help when they realised they had no way of getting back to the mainland .
shortly before 20:30 wells lifeboat was launched , and located the couple by looking for the light from their mobile phone .
they were brought safely ashore a short while later .
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

from now until 18:00 we 're here , bringing you the latest news from around the county .

documents.title: our live coverage today
text: the light evenings are just too hard to resist , so we 're calling it a day for our regular news updates and heading off home .
if a major story breaks , you 'll find the details here .
in the meantime , here 's a quick look at some of the news bites we 've brought you today .

documents.title: tuesday will be warm , sunny and wet
text: it should remain dry tonight , with some mist and fog , and a patchy frost .
temperatures falling to 3c ( 37f ) .
the mist and fog will clear more quickly tomorrow than it did today .
we 'll then see some sunny spells but also some showers which could turn heavy and thundery .
top temperatures , in the sunshine , could reach 20c ( 68f ) .

documents.title: sea defence work finishes ahead of schedule
text: work to protect people and properties from tidal flooding along parts of the north norfolk coast has been completed ahead of schedule .

environment agency contractors began their annual maintenance of the shingle embankment and beach between snettisham and hunstanton on 7 march , repairing any damage or loss of material caused to the embankment during the winter months .
the work is carried out before the start of the bird breeding season , and before the tourist season begins .
the project is estimated to cost £ 150,000 .
completed - 68000m3 of sand and shingle recycled onto norfolk coast - snettisham scalp to hunstanton - and finished 2 days ahead of schedule

documents.title: tractors targeted by thieves
text: satelilte navigation systems are being targeted by thieves in west norfolk .
police have seen a rise in thefts of the specialised devices from tractors in recent weeks .
they 're used for navigating the farm vehicles through fields , and can be worth thousands of pounds .
sgt tom metcalf says they 're looking to increase patrols within the farming community , and is asking for anyone who sees sus activity to contact them .
we 're a large rural area in norfolk and there 's a number of farms that are n't attended overnight , so it 's a matter of looking after your neighbours .
the equipment is high value in monetary terms and also in terms of continuing with daily business . ''

documents.title: herring heydays : trawling back through the archives
text: at the height of the herring industry , 400 million fish could be landed in a single season at great yarmouth and lowestoft .
but after the end of world war one , the industry fell into decline and now just a handful of fishing boats remain .
we 've taken a `` trawl '' back through the photo archives .
in 1928 , these scottish fisherwomen were at work on the largest haul of herrings for the season at great yarmouth , with an estimated value of £ 40,000 .
the fisher-girls would use long poles to push the barrels of herring along the quayside .
the fish would be gutted on the quayside but it was n't all work and no play .
while waiting for the drifters to bring the next catch ashore , there was time for a quick game of draughts .
this was the scene in october 1934 - piles of fishing baskets , known as swills , wait in readiness for the herring season .
there are believed to be 19,000 in this one pile .
the baskets would pile up on the quayside , ready for the driftters to bring in the day 's catch .
before the season got under way , it was important to make sure the nets were ready .
in december 1935 , fisher girls in great yarmouth used this old tram car as a shelter .
these youngsters found the barrels just too hard to resist , scaling the heights of the huge stack near great yarmouth 's nelson monument .

documents.title: witness appeal to fatal road collision
text: police are appealing for witnesses to a fatal road collision between a vehicle and a pedestrian in bradwell near great yarmouth .
emergency services were called to the incident , on burgh road , at around 17:15 on friday .
the pedestrian , a man in his 20s , was taken to the james paget university hospital where he died as a result of the collision .

documents.title: more than 100 motorists caught not buckling up
text: more than 100 drivers were caught not wearing a seatbelt during a week-long campaign by norfolk police .
as part of the campaign , an unmarked hgv was used to target drivers on the a11 and a47 on thursday , 16 march .
on that day , 29 tickets were issued for seatbelt offences , and two drivers were stopped for holding and using their mobile phone at the wheel .
sgt julian ditcham says the hgv 's cab provided an ideal vantage point for officers to spot dangerous driving , and the campaign will be repeated in future .
anyone caught not buckling up may be issued with a traffic offence report , and face a fine , points on their licence or even court action .

documents.title: man to face trial over valentine 's day attack
text: a man has pleaded not guilty to an attack on .
valentine 's day .
that led to a man dying of his injuries in hospital .
mitchell bird , 29 , of cox close , wisbech , pleaded not guilty at cambridge crown court to murdering 35-year-old bradley carter (
mr carter , of west walton , norfolk , was attacked at a house in wisbech on 14 february and died at the queen elizabeth hospital in king 's lynn five days later .
a trial date was provisionally set for 7 august and mr bird was remanded in custody .
author: Mariam Issimdar
BBC News

documents.title: guildhall plans go back to the drawing board
text: ambitious plans to renovate the st george 's guildhall in king 's lynn have been put on hold after the heritage lottery fund ( hlf ) turned down a bid to support the project .
now it 's back to the drawing board for king 's lynn and west norfolk borough council , which put forward the bid for £ 2.7m in december .
the scheme had included repairs to the roof of the medieval building , which is used as a theatre and exhibition space .
it also included the installation of a lift and changing to seating so that the complex could have a flat floor space as well as the raked theatre seating .
the plan was not without its critics , who feared having fewer seats could affect the viability of productions there .

the hlf says it 's unable to support the council 's application , and points out that it has already given nearly £ 9m to other projects in the borough , including greyfriars tower and the south gate .
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: archive : heyday of the herring industry
text: it 's said that at the height of the herring industry in great yarmouth and lowestoft , 60 million of the `` silver darlings '' were landed in a single day .
young women would travel from scotland , following the fishing boats all the way down the east coast , to norfolk and suffolk .
there was little work for the women in the scottish islands , so it was a case of doing whatever work they could for the rest of the year they 'd be unemployed .
working in groups of three , the girls could gut 60 herring a minute - that 's one every second .
two would gut and the third would pack the fish into barrels .
they wrapped their fingers in bits of cotton cloth so they could still grab the knife .
sometimes the action would wear a hole in the cloth and the salt would quite painfully sting the fingers , which could get quite raw .
it was hard work - they had to work right through from the time the drifters arrived in the docks , until the catch was finished .

the heyday of the industry was between 1870 and the beginning of world war one in 1914.. at one time , there were 350 fishing boats in lowestoft , and it was possible to walk from one side of the dock to the other , from boat to boat .
after the war the industry declined , catches were smaller and people 's tastes changed .
with the advent of the fish finger , the silver darlings lost their popularity .

documents.title: helicopter operations unaffected by restructuring
text: the firm which runs helicopter flights to north sea rigs out of norwich airport has had to restructure its us operations .
the american arm of chc helicopter was forced to reorganise its business after facing bankruptcy .
a spokesman for the firm says its operations out of norfolk are unaffected by the move .
meanwhile , a heliport in great yarmouth , formerly used by chc , has been put up for sale .
the north denes airfield has been vacant for the past two years , after the helicopter firm moved their operations to norwich airport .
author: Jo Thewlis
BBC Radio Norfolk

documents.title: football-mad ministers are norwich city fc club chaplains
text: two football-loving norfolk church ministers , who shout for their team from the stands at carrow road at every home match , also offer their support in a quieter way at norwich city 's colney training ground as the club 's chaplains .
author: Network Norfolk

documents.title: cash stolen in petrol station robbery
text: a cashier was threatened with a knife before a quantity of cash was taken from the till of a petrol station .
the incident happened at the bp filling station , on the southbound carriageway of the a11 at thetford on saturday night .
one man stood at the door while the other suspect entered the shop and threatened the cashier , demanding money .
the two men fled from the forecourt , and into woodland .
the member of staff was uninjured .
police are appealing to anyone with information to contact them .

documents.title: turning sunny and warm
text: after a cloudy morning , we can expect a warm and sunny afternoon , with temperatures reaching 14c ( 57f ) .
here 's a selection of `` misty morning '' shots taken by some of you who 've signed up to be bbc weather watchers and rusty arrow assures us their photo is in colour .

documents.title: good vibrations for festival
text: the line-up has been announced for this year 's vw whitenoise festival , which returns to euston park near thetford in august .
coinciding with the actual brian wilson 's 50th anniversary of pet sounds tour , tribute act the uk beach boys will be among those taking to the stage at the music , arts and motoring festival .
the festival began in norfolk 15 years ago , with previous venues including the norfolk showground , fritton lake and wolterton hall .
this year 's event takes place over three days , 3-6 august .
tickets are now on sale .

documents.title: drones , more anti-speeding measures
text: rural roads in norfolk are likely to get more speed surveillance .
that 's according to the police and crime commissioner , lorne green .
mr green says a lot of `` speeding infractions '' take place on b roads and rural roads , and he 's determined to do something about it .
speaking to bbc radio norfolk 's nick conrad , he also said they 'll be launching a major campaign to recruit special constables , and hinted at the use of drones for future crime investigations .
i must n't say too much today , but maybe we can speed up the investigations of hare coursing , rural crime , search and rescue , if the constabulary had drones watch this space . ''

documents.title: keep your eyes peeled for insect invader
text: the call has gone out for people to report sightings of an invader ant .
known as lasius neglectus , it arrived in the uk eight years ago and is the first non-native ant species to have made a home here .
although it might seem harmless , the invasive garden pest can have a severe negative impact on ground foragers , such as woodlice and beetles .
doreen wells , the norfolk county recorder for ants , says the insect has been recently discovered in cambridgeshire .
it looks very similar to the common brown ant and doreen warns it could easily slip into this county - she 's appealing for anyone to .
report sightings to her .
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: ants native or non-native ?
text: with members of the public urged to report sightings of invasive garden ants , would you know how to spot one ?
the lasius neglectus might seem harmless , but it 's a widespread pest that forms super colonies - the largest ever found in the uk consisted of 35,000 ants crammed into a small fuse box .
so how does it compare to our native common ant , lasius niger ?
the ant is believed to be native to western asia and usually nests in the ground beneath stones or paving slabs .
as the queens rarely fly , it can be spread with the movement of plants from infested areas .
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: six-year-old girl plans 50-mile bike ride for charity
text: a six-year-old girl from norwich is hoping to raise thousands of pounds to thank the hospital team which helped save her grandmother 's life .
later this week , georgia stallard and her granddad will cycle the 50 miles ( 80 km ) between the hook of holland and amsterdam .
georgia has been describing her bike : `` it 's pink and blue and so far i 've cycled 70 miles with it - it does n't change into gear one , but it changes into all the other gears . ''
the keen cyclists have already raised £ 800 for the oncology department at the hospital .

text: it 's a day off for pupils of sheringham community primary and nursery .
the school is closed for the day , because of a water leak in the boiler room .

documents.title: diabetes health scheme being piloted
text: a public health scheme to stop people getting diabetes is being piloted in the county , with invites for people whose blood tests show them at high risk of type 2 diabetes .
they will be offered advice on diet and lifestyle .

gp linda hunter , who worked on the bid to run the trial , says it aims to try and actually prevent people going on to get diabetes : `` this is about giving people knowledge to be able to get to a point where they can take some control and make a difference . ''

documents.title: successful night for international canaries
text: the four norwich city players who featured in yesterday 's world cup qualifiers appear to have come through without any injury worries .
goalkeeper michael mcgovern kept a clean sheet as northern ireland beat norway 2-0 .
canaries striker kyle lafferty came on as a substitute with five minutes to play .
norwich captain russell martin almost scored in the opening minute as scotland edged past slovenia 1-0 at hampden park .
steven naismith played for most of the second half but it was a former city striker , chris martin , who scored the only goal .

documents.title: wroxham relegated from ryman league
text: wroxham 's relegation from the ryman league was confirmed over the weekend with five matches of the season still to play .
the yachtsmen were beaten 1-0 at home by aveley , a result which leaves them bottom of ryman division one north .
they 're 18 points from safety having won just six of their 41 matches .
wroxham manager david coyle says he expects to stay on as manager at trafford park .
`` i want to be here and the chairman has indicated that he wants me here next year , '' he said .
`` i think over time i can build something that can be really positive here . ''

the low cloud will be quite quick to lift , particularly in the south of the region , but parts of north norfolk and suffolk could potentially remain cloudy for much of the day and with the on-shore , north-easterly breeze it 's going to struggle with the temperatures , with a maximum of 8c ( 46f ) there .
